title: How to Stop a Cake from Browning Too Much

steps.headline: Check that the cake pan is deep enough for the cake.
steps.description: A shallow pan carries more risk of browning than a deep one.

steps.headline: Line the sides of the cake pan.
steps.description: Use two layers of brown paper and two layers of baking paper. Allow this paper to extend above the pan about 5 centimeter (2.0 in) to 7 centimeter (2.8 in). This paper "wall" will help to protect the cake top from browning.

steps.headline: Smooth the cake before adding it to the oven.
steps.description: A flatter surface made by a spatula or knife can help to prevent uneven browning.

steps.headline: Check the alignment of the oven shelves.
steps.description: The shelf used should not place the cake too close to the heat source. Bake the cake in the lower half of the oven.

steps.headline: Keep an eye on the cake as it bakes.
steps.description: If it appears to be browning unevenly, turn it in quarters several times during baking.

steps.headline: Add a layer of kitchen foil.
steps.description: Halfway through baking, you can place a layer of kitchen foil over the top of the cake to prevent browning, especially where it has a fruit or caramelized top.

tyn: Baking paper and brown paper; scissors
Spatula or knife for smoothing cake
